Description: Background Access to employment and gaining economic independence is critical for migrant women to achieve positive outcomes for themselves, their families, and communities. Migrant women need access to meaningful jobs which fully engage their qualifications, skills, experiences, education and which allow them to utilise the experiences and skills gained abroad as well as in their countries of origin. Description: With over 800 species found in Ireland, mosses, liverworts and hornworts (collectively known as bryophytes) form a large component of our biodiversity and play significant ecological roles. However, many species have declined and even vanished from our landscapes due to pressures such as habitat loss, land use change and pollution. According to the Irish Red List of Bryophytes, around 20% of our bryophyte species are threatened with extinction. Complementary to in situ (on-site) conservation efforts, ex situ (off-site) conservation techniques, such as in vitro cultivation (tissue culture) and cryopreservation (long-term storage in liquid nitrogen), can act as a reserve for rare and threatened species and their genetic diversity.  This talk will highlight the work being undertaken at the National Botanic Gardens on an ex situ conservation programme for Ireland‚Äôs threatened and legally protected bryophyte species.
Title: Insights on Off-Site Bryophytes - Ex Situ  conservation of mosses
Subtitle: Join Dr Christina Campbell for the fascinating insight into the world of mosses and liverworts

Connecting People with Jobs: Impact evaluation of Ireland‚Äôs Active Labour Market Policies will be launched on 13th March 2024. This is the output of an OECD and European Commission project on policy impact evaluation through the use of linked administrative and survey data. The project aims to raise the quality of the data collected and promote the use of evaluation techniques to measure the effectiveness of Active Labour Market Policies (ALMPs) so that countries can better evaluate and design policies to benefit people. The report consists of a Counterfactual Impact Evaluation (CIE) of both the Community Employment and T√∫s programmes, two of the key active labour market programmes operating in Ireland, as well as sequence analysis of a range of ALMPs. The report is published as part of an OECD series of country studies, Connecting People with Jobs, and can be accessed on 13th March at the link above. An accompanying technical report provides more detail on the data and techniques underpinning the analysis in the main report. Launch of the Country Report The morning session is the launch of the country report and will present the key findings of the report to a wide audience. After the presentation of the key results of the report, participants will have the opportunity to ask questions and share their thoughts. Launch of the Technical Report The afternoon session takes a more detailed look into the data and methodology used in the report, including the use of DSP administrative data, the application of Counterfactual Impact Evaluation methodology and detailed outline of the results in the report. After the presentation, audience members will have the opportunity to discuss these aspects with the authors.
Title: Impact evaluation of Ireland‚Äôs Active Labour Market Policies
Subtitle: Please join us for the launch of ‚ÄòConnecting People with Jobs: Impact evaluation of Ireland‚Äôs Active Labour Market Policies‚Äô

Groups and organisations can apply for grants between ‚Ç¨1,000 and ‚Ç¨40,000 for projects delivered by February 2025. For larger or phased projects, funding may be committed for 2-5 years. Description: What is STAG? STAG stands for - Students for Treborth Action Group. We are a student led project group that volunteers with Treborth Botanical Garden. Why should you come to Treborth? Treborth is a wonderful place to go to find community, learn about plants and gardening or even bring what you've learnt about (e.g., aquascape or wildflower surveying) to the table. Or if you want to learn how to do or make something (e.g., look after your secateurs or how to make your very own mini terrarium), that can be arranged too! What is a 'Work Party'? These are where STAG and FTBG (Friends of Treborth Botanical Garden) come together to garden, chat and at midday eat lunch (bring your own pack lunch - however, every now and then in the future we might have bigger events and have everyone bring in lovely food to share). Gardening activities will change from week to week but some things you can expect to be getting involved with are potting, seeding, planting, weeding, and mulching. However, there are all kinds of other things that may be happening in the future that you will be able to get involved with including tree work. Housekeeping: Please remember to bring your own pack lunch if you're staying past midday. Don't forget to bring suitable warm clothing and waterproofs and a good pair of wellies/boots. We will provide gardening gloves and everything else.
